#Text=Dortmund
#Text=Dortmund
#Text=( Low German : Düörpm ; Latin : Tremonia ) is a city with a population of about 600,000 in the North Rhine-Westphalia region in Germany .
#Text=It is in the middle part of the state and is considered to be the administrative , commercial and cultural centre of the Ruhr area with some 5.21 million inhabitants ( 2017 ) .
#Text=The city is famous for its beer , football , events and for shopping .
#Text=Understand
#Text=The city pops up first when people think of the Ruhr valley , and that 's no surprise .
#Text=It is the largest Ruhr city , the third largest by population after Cologne and Düsseldorf , and the geographical center of the North Rhine-Westphalia state .
#Text=Worldwide , the city is foremost know for beer ( pale export/lager beer called Dortmunder ) and the famous sports club Ballspielverein Borussia 09 , Borussia Dortmund or BVB for short .
#Text=But therein another , altogether gentler , side to this former industrial powerhouse .

#Text=Modern Dortmund is vibrant and cultural , well-known for excellent shopping , a range of fascinating museums and theaters , one of Germany 's most surprising startup scenes ( not quite on the same level as Berlin , but ahead of the Rhine-Ruhr area and even Munich ) , and with half the city given over to parks and gardens , enough green areas to sooth the sense .
#Text=And yes , the city is no classy beauty , and rough at first glance , though pretty honest , adorable and cordial at the second .
#Text=History
#Text=Founded around the year 882 , Dortmund became an Imperial Free City .
#Text=Throughout the 13th and 14th centuries , it was the " chief city " of the Rhine , Westphalia , and of the Netherlandish Circle of the Hanseatic League .

#Text=After the Thirty Years ' War , the city was destroyed , and decreased in significance until the onset of industrialization ; then , it became one of Germany 's most important coal , steel and beer centres .
#Text=Dortmund acquired the nickname Stahlstadt ( Steel City ) in the 19th century , when it became the world center of steel production .
#Text=Consequently , the city was one of the most heavily bombed cities in Germany during World War II .
#Text=The devastating bombing raids of 12 March 1945 , with more than 1,110 aircraft , destroyed 98 % of buildings in the inner city center , a record to a single target in this war .
#Text=Much of what you see in the city center was built in the last 50 years .
#Text=The region has adapted since the collapse of its steel and coal industries , and shifted to high technology , biomedical technology , micro systems technology and also services .

#Text=In November 2017 , according to a study by data of German National Statistics Office , the National Employment Agency , Mercer , Handelsblatt , Numbeo and Immowelt , Dortmund was ranked as the seventh most livable city in Germany for expats .

#Text=In September 2017 , The New York Times praised the city of Dortmund , which has adapted since the collapse of its century long steel and coal industries and shifted to high technology biomedical technology , micro systems technology and services , as the hidden star of structural change with a good quality of life for employers .
#Text=According to the 2017 Global Least & Most Stressful Cities Ranking , Dortmund is one of the least stressful cities in the world .
#Text=It 's ranked 27th out of 150 between Copenhagen and Vancouver and highly ranked in the category Traffic & Public Transport , Gender equality and debt per capital .
#Text=When to visit
#Text=The best times for Dortmund are late spring to early autumn , its peak season for tourist .

#Text=The summers tend to be sunny and warm around 25°C ( 77°F ) , during the November and December 5°C you can find several Christmas markets in the city , in combination with the festive mood , it s a nice time to visit .
#Text=Tourist office
#Text=Dortmund Tourist and Information Office
#Text=, Kampstraße 80 , ☏ +49 231-18999222 , fax : +49 231-18999333 , ✉ info@dortmund-tourismus.de .
#Text=M - F 10:00 - 18:00 , Sa Su holidays 10:00 - 16:00 ; New Year and New Year 's Eve 10:00 - 23:00 ; closed on December 25 and 26 .
#Text=By plane
#Text=Dortmund airport
#Text=( DTM ) .
#Text=Home of several low-cost airlines ( easyJet , Wizzair ) , it serves mainly national and European travellers , with a particularly heavy focus on Eastern Europe .

#Text=Unusually for a German airport , there is no direct train or tram connection to the airport , but there are shuttle buses between the airport and Dortmund Central Station or Holzwickede Station .
#Text=From and to Central Station :
#Text=A non-stop shuttle-bus can be found opposite the main railway station .
#Text=The journey lasts 25 - 30 min and costs € 6.5 per passenger ( 6-14 children € 2 ; younger children free ) .
#Text=This bus service is not covered by a travelcard .
#Text=Via Aplerbeck
#Text=The 440 bus travels past Aplerbeck where passengers can change to the Stadtbahn U47 which will go to the Hbf via the major Stadtbahn hub , Stadtgarten .
#Text=The journey is approximately 45 min .
#Text=Tickets cost € 2.50 or a travelcard can be used .
#Text=This service runs more frequently than the shuttle bus .
#Text=From Holzwickede Station :
#Text=A bus service ( €3/passenger ) , runs regularly about every 15 minutes between 05:00 and 23:00 .
#Text=The trip to the terminal building takes approx. 5 minutes .
#Text=By taxi :
#Text=The trip costs around € 25 to the City Centre .
#Text=Drivers operate on the meter ; if they do n't , get a different taxi !
#Text=Duesseldorf Airport
#Text=( DUS ) can also be used and may be a better option , especially for passengers who prefer major carriers .
#Text=It is a 45-60 minute drive away from Dortmund .
#Text=Direct train services also run between Dortmund Central Station and Düsseldorf Airport operated by Deutsche Bahn .
#Text=Düsseldorf
#Text=Airport serves a variety of long haul destinations in North America and Asia , as well as short haul services throughout Europe .
#Text=By train
#Text=Dortmund central station
#Text=( Dortmund Hauptbahnhof ) , Königswall 15 , 44137 .
#Text=This is a major stop for Deutsche Bahn ( German state railway ) and has over 600 departing trains on a typical weekday .
#Text=There are different types of trains such as S-Bahn , Regionalbahn , and Regionalexpress .
#Text=The station is a terminus for some Thalys trains ( usually 3 per day ) .
#Text=Dortmund Hörde Bahnhof
#Text=( Hörde Hauptbahnhof ) , Hörder Bahnhofstraße , 44263 .
#Text=This is the second biggest stop in Dortmund and it is classified by Deutsche Bahn as a category 4 station .
#Text=Trains run hourly , except for the RB 59 ( Hellweg-Bahn ) service , which runs every 30 minutes on weekdays .
#Text=There are additional services on weekdays during the peak hour
#Text=All tickets will have to be validated before departure .
#Text=For the trains like Regionalbahn or Regionalexpress there 's an orange machine before you go up the stairs to the platform , where you have to stamp your ticket .

#Text=The Stadtbahn Dortmund ( DSW21 ) tickets for the local Stadtbahn ( light rail ) and Straßenbahn ( tram ) service must be validated on the actual trains although you will find stamp boxes at the entrance to the platform as well .
#Text=Deutsche Bahn
